title: Segmentation-Free Integration of Nuclei Morphology and Spatial Transcriptomics for Retinal Images
author: Eduard Chelebian (Uppsala University), Carolina Wählby (Uppsala University), Pratiti Dasgupta (University of California, Los Angeles), Zain Samadi (University of California, Los Angeles), Amjad Askary (University of California, Los Angeles), ...
background: Integrating data from imaging-based spatial transcriptomics and cell nuclei morphology to enhance the classification of cell types in samples where direct segmentation is difficult.
contribution: This study introduces SEFI (Segmentation-Free Integration) to solve the challenge of nuclei segmentation in spatial transcriptomics, achieving improved clustering of gene expression data through self-supervised learning of morphological features.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods often rely on segmentation which can be challenging due to densification and complexity in tissue structure.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by employing a segmentation-free approach that uses morphological representations to enhance clustering accuracy.

key_innovation: Utilizes self-supervised learning to extract and leverage morphological features from imaging data without requiring explicit segmentation.
real_world_impact: The method could significantly streamline genomic research in complex tissues like the retina, potentially leading to better understanding of developmental biology and diseases.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.self-supervised learning: **Self-supervised learning** is a machine learning paradigm where the model learns from unlabeled data by generating supervisory signals from the data itself.
